reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: Streaming video is outside my wheelhouse. I don’t fully understand shifting viewer habits, global content rights or the technology race. I stick to businesses I can explain on a cocktail napkin – consumer staples, banks, insurance and utilities. 
2. Moat: Netflix has a big subscriber base and a strong brand, but it faces relentless competition from Disney, Amazon, Apple and an army of smaller rivals. I’m skeptical that any one of them has a durable castle wall around its business when everyone’s spending billions on content. 
3. Management & Capital Allocation: Reed Hastings built a great operation, but issuing more stock and piling on debt to fund content makes me nervous. They pay no dividends and reinvest at low returns on capital – not the sort of alchemy I admire in a management team. 
4. Financial Health & Consistency: A debt-to-equity ratio near 3.8 and an ROE of 5.5% are red flags. Earnings are inconsistent, and owner earnings have actually been shrinking. That’s no financial fortress. 
5. Valuation: At a current market value roughly ten times my conservative intrinsic value ($74 per share), there’s no margin of safety. You don’t want to buy the farm at peak price. 
6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: The economics of content creation push costs higher, and pricing power is limited by fierce competition. Technological shifts could erode subscriber loyalty faster than Netflix can produce hits. 
7. Opportunity Cost: Given the choice, I’d lean into businesses like Coca-Cola or Bank of America – strong moats, honest stewards, fortress balance sheets and sensible valuations. Why overpay for a complex media business when simpler, predictable franchises are available at fair prices?

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 5.5%; High debt to equity ratio of 3.8; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 16.8% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Excellent ROE consistency: 8/10 periods >15% (avg: 17.5%) - indicates durable competitive advantage; Decent operating margins (avg: 38.5%) suggest some competitive advantage; High performance stability (82.4%) suggests strong competitive moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern; Good book value CAGR: 11.8%

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
